Utterance: Hi again! It’s great to see you back. How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie! I’ve been okay, I guess. Just dealing with everything with my dad and trying to balance my work.
I appreciate you sharing that. How has the situation with your dad been?
It’s been tough. Some days are better than others. I try to stay positive, but it wears on you, you know?
Absolutely, that makes sense. Have you found any coping strategies that help you during those tougher days?
Well, I’ve been trying to meditate a bit more. It helps me calm down when I feel overwhelmed.
That’s great to hear! Mindfulness can be very beneficial. How has that practice been for you?
It’s been good! I’m still getting the hang of it, but I feel a little more centered afterward.
That’s a positive step. Are there specific thoughts or feelings that come up during meditation that you’d like to explore?
Sometimes I think about my dad a lot, and it makes me anxious. I worry about what will happen next.
Those worries are completely understandable. Have you had any conversations with your dad about how he’s feeling?
A little, but he doesn’t like to talk about it much. He wants to stay strong for us.
It’s common for people to want to protect their loved ones from difficult discussions. How does that affect you?
It makes me feel helpless sometimes. I want to support him, but it’s hard when he shuts me out.
That sounds challenging. Have you considered ways to express your feelings to him?
I’ve thought about writing him a letter. I could say everything I want to without putting him on the spot.
That’s a wonderful idea! Writing can be a powerful way to communicate. Would you like to explore what you might want to include in that letter?
Sure! I want to tell him how much I love him and how I’m here for him no matter what.
That’s beautiful. You could also express your own feelings about the situation. How do you feel about your dad’s illness?
I feel scared and sad, honestly. It’s hard to watch him go through this.
Those feelings are valid. It’s natural to feel scared when a loved one is unwell. Have you found any outlets for those emotions?
I’ve been talking to my friends more about it. They help me feel less alone.
That’s great to hear! Having a support system is important. Do you feel comfortable sharing with them what you’re experiencing?
I do, mostly. I think they understand, but sometimes I don’t want to burden them.
It’s understandable to feel that way, but remember, friends often appreciate being let in. It can strengthen your connection.
Yeah, I guess I just don’t want to seem like I’m complaining all the time.
It’s okay to share your struggles. It doesn’t mean you’re complaining; it’s about being honest with those you trust.
That makes sense. I’ll try to be more open.
That’s a positive step. Speaking of openness, how have you been feeling about your dreams since we last spoke?
They’ve been pretty much the same. Still those stress dreams, mostly about my dad.
Have you noticed any patterns in the dreams? Maybe certain triggers that lead to them?
Not really, but I think they come when I’m feeling particularly anxious or overwhelmed.
That’s insightful. It sounds like your subconscious is processing your feelings. Have you tried any techniques to cope with those dreams?
I’ve been trying to write them down when I wake up. It helps to get them out of my head.
That’s a great strategy! Writing can help externalize those feelings. Have you found it helpful?
Yeah, it feels a bit like I’m releasing them, even if just a little.
That’s wonderful! It’s a form of catharsis. Would you like to explore any other coping strategies today?
Maybe some relaxation techniques? I could use some more tools to help me unwind.
Absolutely! Have you tried progressive muscle relaxation before?
No, I haven’t. What’s that?
It involves tensing and then relaxing different muscle groups in your body. It can help alleviate physical tension and promote relaxation.
That sounds interesting!
Great! Let’s practice it together. You can start by taking a deep breath in… and as you exhale, let your shoulders drop.
Okay, I’m doing that.
Now, let’s tense your shoulders for a few seconds… and release. How does that feel?
That feels nice!
Wonderful! You can practice this technique whenever you feel tension building. It’s a great way to reconnect with your body.
I’ll definitely try that.
I’m glad to hear that! As we wrap up today, what’s one goal you’d like to focus on before our next session?
I’d like to write that letter to my dad and practice some of the relaxation techniques we discussed.
Those sound like excellent goals! I’m looking forward to hearing how that goes.
Thanks, Ellie! I appreciate your help.
You’re very welcome! Take care of yourself, and I’ll see you next time.
Bye!
Goodbye!
